conclusion: Analyze velocity-time graphs to determine when objects are farthest apart.
Object A has a linear velocity-time graph, indicating constant acceleration.
Object B has a curved velocity-time graph, indicating variable acceleration.
Both objects start from the same position at time t = 0.
Area under velocity-time graph represents displacement.
For object A, displacement is a triangle under the graph.
For object B, displacement is more complex due to curve.
Calculate displacement for both objects by finding area under graphs.
Maximum separation occurs when difference in displacement is greatest.
Object B's velocity decreases initially and then increases.
At time t1, object B's velocity is at its minimum.
After t1, object B starts to accelerate and catch up with object A.
At time t2, both objects have the same velocity.
Maximum separation occurs just before object B starts to catch up with object A.
Objects are farthest apart at time t1.
